1. Time complexity: The time complexity of the Smith-Waterman algorithm depends on the number of positions in the sequences being compared. Specifically, the time complexity is O(n^2), where n is the length of the shorter sequence. This is because the algorithm has to compare each element in the shorter sequence with every element in the longer sequence, which leads to a total of n^2 comparisons.
2. Space complexity: The space complexity of the Smith-Waterman algorithm is O(n), where n is the length of the shorter sequence. This is because the algorithm needs to store the current best score and the corresponding position in the longer sequence for each element in the shorter sequence. The total amount of memory required is thus n times the size of a single element in the sequences.
3. Optimal case: The optimal case for the Smith-Waterman algorithm occurs when the two sequences are identical, in which case the time complexity is O(n), and the space complexity is O(n).
4. Worst-case scenario: The worst-case scenario for the Smith-Waterman algorithm occurs when the two sequences are completely random and have no similarity, in which case the time complexity is O(n^2), and the space complexity is O(n).
5. Average-case scenario: The average-case scenario for the Smith-Waterman algorithm is typically somewhere in between the optimal and worst-case scenarios. The time complexity is typically O(n^2), and the space complexity is O(n).
